"allienating prefix". The full range of functions of k'e- is huge. It can be used as indefinite non-human pronoun, can code arguments that are unspecified, can be used to indicate a GREAT DISTANCE or a stretch of TIME Described in more detail in Thompson 1991 INterestingly, if talking about possession of animal part, k'e- can actually appear twice 1s-K'E-K'E-head 'my [animal's] head', so indeed, k'e does not only mark indefinite possessor (implicit argument), but also something about relation (the second k'e)

It is also used to construct vocative forms of the kinship terms "aunt" "uncle". be/me- is used if the possessor is not human, has no control over the possessed (ironing of the clothes; dirt on his hands) go- is used to refer to unspecified human possessors, like "someone"

MorphemeNom.Remark: Pre-nominal possessive pronouns and the two linkers are always prefixed by one of three nominal classifiers. The three s are s-, m- and the zero morpheme ∅-. They differ from typical possessive s in Oceanic languages in that they are not relational s, but rather agree with the lexical gender of the head noun: In contrast to other Oceanic languages [compare e.g. Lichtenberk, 1983, 2009b], the choice of is independent of the possessor’s intentions with regard to the possessum. In some cases, the choice of depends on whether a noun fits into a certain semantic domain. For example, when talking about the possession of animals, everyone will use inevitably the same (∅-), independent of whether they intend to eat, breed, sell or play with the animal.
